definitions.definition: A long, thin piece of land; any long, thin area.
definitions.example: The countries were in dispute over the ownership of a strip of desert about 100 metres wide.

definitions.definition: (usually countable, sometimes uncountable) A long, thin piece of any material; any such material collectively.
definitions.example: I have some strip left over after fitting out the kitchen.

definitions.definition: A comic strip.
A landing strip.
A strip steak.
A street with multiple shopping or entertainment possibilities.
The playing area, roughly 14 meters by 2 meters.
The uniform of a football team, or the same worn by supporters.
A trough for washing ore.
The issuing of a projectile from a rifled gun without acquiring the spiral motion.
A television series aired at the same time daily (or at least on Mondays to Fridays), so that it appears as a strip straight across the weekly schedule.
The act of removing one's clothes; a striptease.
definitions.example: She stood up on the table and did a strip.

definitions.definition: (of games) Denotes a version of a game in which losing players must progressively remove their clothes.
To remove or take away, often in strips or stripes.
definitions.example: Norm will strip the old varnish before painting the chair.

definitions.definition: (usually intransitive) To take off clothing.
definitions.example: Seeing that no one else was about, he stripped and dived into the river.

definitions.definition: To perform a striptease.
definitions.example: In the seedy club, a group of drunken men were watching a woman stripping.

definitions.definition: To take away something from (someone or something); to plunder; to divest.
definitions.example: The athlete was stripped of his medal after failing a drugs test.

definitions.definition: To remove cargo from (a container).
To remove (the thread or teeth) from a screw, nut, or gear, especially inadvertently by overtightening.
definitions.example: Don't tighten that bolt any more or you'll strip the thread.

definitions.definition: To fail in the thread; to lose the thread, as a bolt, screw, or nut.
To remove color from hair, cloth, etc. to prepare it to receive new color.
To remove all cards of a particular suit from another player. (See also strip-squeeze.)
To empty (tubing) by applying pressure to the outside of (the tubing) and moving that pressure along (the tubing).
To milk a cow, especially by stroking and compressing the teats to draw out the last of the milk.
To press out the ripe roe or milt from fishes, for artificial fecundation.
To run a television series at the same time daily (or at least on Mondays to Fridays), so that it appears as a strip straight across the weekly schedule.
To pare off the surface of (land) in strips.
To remove the overlying earth from (a deposit).
To pass; to get clear of; to outstrip.
To remove the metal coating from (a plated article), as by acids or electrolytic action.
To remove fibre, flock, or lint from; said of the teeth of a card when it becomes partly clogged.
To pick the cured leaves from the stalks of (tobacco) and tie them into "hands".
To remove the midrib from (tobacco leaves).
